page.title: 20BELIEVE IT OR NOT
page.content: Some two miles by road from Coverack, on the road crossing Crousa Downs between Penhallick and St. Keverne, stands{a rock}about which there is a {strange legend.}It is called{Tide {Rock,}and is simply an ordinary rock protruding from the ground, which has a small hollow in the upper surface. This hollow invariably contains some water. Legend has it that the state of the tide can be predicted according to {the amount of water in the hollow; when the tide is in the hollow is full, and conversely, when the tide is out very little water is to be found in the rock. It is also said that{the {water in the hollow is as salty as the {sea.}Since the water is very murky and appears most unpalatable, I leave it to the truly inquisitive to discover whether this really is so.
